results.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column charges Justice Department with making only listless attempts to get China to make available to FBI interrogators Charlie Trie, former Little Rock restaurateur whose heavy contributions to Pres Clinton's campaign enabled him to bring notorious Chinese arms dealer Wang Jun to White House meeting; notes that China might well shield Wang, but Trie is US citizen; adds that neither Congress nor State Department has asked China's help; quotes Sen John Glenn's letter objecting to cost of sending investigators overseas (M)
results.snippet: After seven months listlessly poking around ''the Asian connection,'' Lee Radek, the Justice Department bureaucrat in charge of what is plaintively called the ''Public Integrity'' section, has still not asked the State Department to request that...
results.lead_paragraph: After seven months listlessly poking around ''the Asian connection,'' Lee Radek, the Justice Department bureaucrat in charge of what is plaintively called the ''Public Integrity'' section, has still not asked the State Department to request that China make available Yah Lin (Charlie) Trie to F.B.I. interrogators. Trie is Bill Clinton's former favorite Little Rock restaurateur, and is now presumed to be in Beijing on his U.S. passport. His heavy contributions to the Clinton campaign enabled him to bring Wang Jun, China's most notorious arms dealer, to a White House meeting with the President.

results.abstract: Ira Berkow Sports of The Times column discusses victories by Utah Jazz in third and fourth games of NBA championship series against Chicago Bulls; photo (M)

headline.main: Cutting The Bulls Down to Size

results.snippet: THIS is not the first time that the Bulls, or their individual members, have been stunned by John Stockton, as was the case Sunday night when Stockton, whose visage is as straight as a string, appeared to have watched too many Michael Jordan...
results.lead_paragraph: THIS is not the first time that the Bulls, or their individual members, have been stunned by John Stockton, as was the case Sunday night when Stockton, whose visage is as straight as a string, appeared to have watched too many Michael Jordan highlight films and did his own impersonation, madly and sweetly. Stockton, it turns out, responds to challenges, too.

results.abstract: Interview with Francois Faiveley, director of Domaine Faiveley, possibly largest vineyard owner in Burgundy, France; Francois is sixth generation to head domaine since it was founded in 1825; in 1934, his grandfather founded Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, one of most successful promotional ventures in modern history of wine; confrerie, society with chapters all over world, holds regular dinners to celebrate, promote and drink wines of Burgundy; photos (M)

headline.main: His Passions: Fast Trains and Burgundy

results.snippet: COMING down to Burgundy from Paris on the sleek, high-speed train, it occurred to me that the 90-minute trip would not have been possible were it not for Faiveley Industries, the Paris-based company that makes doors, brakes and other vital rail...
results.lead_paragraph: COMING down to Burgundy from Paris on the sleek, high-speed train, it occurred to me that the 90-minute trip would not have been possible were it not for Faiveley Industries, the Paris-based company that makes doors, brakes and other vital rail parts, not just for the T.G.V., but for trains all over the world. When Francois Faiveley met me on the platform at Dijon, my thoughts abruptly switched from trains to wine. Mr. Faiveley is chairman of the industrial firm and also the director of Domaine Faiveley, possibly the largest vineyard owner in Burgundy.

results.abstract: Unmanned cargo vessel smashes into Russian Mir space station during practice docking, most serious collision ever involving manned spacecraft; impact sends Mir reeling, knocks out much of its power supply and forces astronauts to seal off punctured compartment; officials say two Russians and one American aboard are not hurt and are in no immediate danger; accident damages American medical experiments and makes American astronaut Michael Foale's sleeping quarters unusable; raises new questions about aging Mir, which has suffered fire and near collison with supply vessel in recent months; American lawmakers say NASA is wrong to station Americans on board; Russians say Mir is safe; diagram; photos (M)

headline.main: Russian Space Station Damaged In Collision With a Cargo Vessel

results.snippet: An unmanned cargo vessel smashed into the Russian Mir space station today during a practice docking in the most serious collision ever involving a manned spacecraft.     The impact sent Mir reeling, knocked out much of its power supply and punctured...
results.lead_paragraph: An unmanned cargo vessel smashed into the Russian Mir space station today during a practice docking in the most serious collision ever involving a manned spacecraft. The impact sent Mir reeling, knocked out much of its power supply and punctured part of the space station, forcing the two Russians and an American on board to scramble to seal off a compartment. Space officials said the astronauts were not injured and were in no immediate danger.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-13    Congo Government Troops Arrest Opposition Leader  Government soldiers in Congo burst into the home of the leading opposition politician, Etienne Tshisekedi, and arrested him and his wife. The arrest came hours after Mr....
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Congo Government Troops Arrest Opposition Leader Government soldiers in Congo burst into the home of the leading opposition politician, Etienne Tshisekedi, and arrested him and his wife. The arrest came hours after Mr. Tshisekedi defied self-proclaimed President Laurent Kabila's ban on political meetings and held a rally at the University of Kinshasa. A1 Clinton Rings Ecological Alarm President Clinton told a special session of the United Nations that severe droughts, floods and epidemics would ravish the earth if countries ignored the ''real and imminent'' problem of pollution. results.abstract: Russian space officials say that it will take two weeks to transport vital repair equipment to stricken Mir space station, which was seriously damaged when unmanned Progress cargo vessel slammed into it on June 25 (M)

headline.main: Tools to Fix Space Station to Arrive in 2 Weeks

results.snippet: Russian space officials said today that it would take two weeks to transport vital repair equipment to the stricken Mir space station .    The station was seriously damaged on Wednesday when an unmanned Progress cargo vessel slammed into it,...
results.lead_paragraph: Russian space officials said today that it would take two weeks to transport vital repair equipment to the stricken Mir space station . The station was seriously damaged on Wednesday when an unmanned Progress cargo vessel slammed into it, curtailing Mir's power supply and forcing the two Russians and an American on board to seal off one of its seven compartments, the Spektr module.

results.abstract: Three-man crew slowly returns Mir space station to normal in wake of collision with unmanned cargo ship; C Michael Foale, NASA astronaut aboard Mir, comments (S)

headline.main: Mir Space Station Slowly Returns to Normal

results.snippet: The three-man crew on the Mir space station worked in the dark today, gripping flashlights in their mouths to keep their hands free.    One of the three, C. Michael Foale, a NASA astronaut, said, ''Slowly, slowly, we've gotten things back to...
results.lead_paragraph: The three-man crew on the Mir space station worked in the dark today, gripping flashlights in their mouths to keep their hands free. One of the three, C. Michael Foale, a NASA astronaut, said, ''Slowly, slowly, we've gotten things back to normal.''

results.abstract: M G Lord reviews art exhibit Exploring the Art of Space at Pasadena Convention Center, Pasadena, Calif; photos (L)

headline.main: New Visions of the Cosmos Now That It's Close at Hand

results.snippet: FROM THE PLUCKY COMET  that upstaged the ''Adoration of the Magi'' in Giotto's Scrovengi Chapel frescoes in Padua to the fiery swirls of van Gogh's ''Starry Night,'' celestial objects have long fascinated artists. Whistler, Goya and Paul Klee also...
results.lead_paragraph: FROM THE PLUCKY COMET that upstaged the ''Adoration of the Magi'' in Giotto's Scrovengi Chapel frescoes in Padua to the fiery swirls of van Gogh's ''Starry Night,'' celestial objects have long fascinated artists. Whistler, Goya and Paul Klee also studied the heavens after dark. During the last 50 years, however, breakthroughs in astronomy and space exploration have changed how artists portray the cosmos. Where once it glittered with remote objects onto which romantic longing could be projected, it now beckons with reachable destinations, whose topographical details -- craters, ice fields, volcanic ridges -- have been revealed. While the images beamed back from robotic spacecraft are by definition ''up close,'' they are far from ''personal.'' Artists, though, have interpreted scientific information in ways that heighten intimacy. In 1971 and '72, the painter and printmaker Vija Celmins (who has just won a MacArthur grant) took actual images of the lunar surface returned by the Surveyor lander and re-created them, detail by painstaking detail, in a richly layered pencil drawing. ''I was attracted by the cool blandness of the scientific image,'' she said, and wanted to translate it into something ''that like the moon, had real dust.''

results.snippet: Kimberly Jeanne Holden and Gregg Andrew Pasquarelli, both architectural interns, were married yesterday in Winter Harbor, Me. The Quaker ceremony, led by Dr. William Rogers, took place at the home of the bride's family.    The bride, a cum laude...
results.lead_paragraph: Kimberly Jeanne Holden and Gregg Andrew Pasquarelli, both architectural interns, were married yesterday in Winter Harbor, Me. The Quaker ceremony, led by Dr. William Rogers, took place at the home of the bride's family. The bride, a cum laude graduate of the University of Vermont, and the bridegroom, a graduate of Villanova University, received master's degrees in architecture from Columbia University. She works at John Ciardullo Associates in New York; he works as a project manager at Greg Lynn Form in Hoboken, N.J.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard trouble-plagued Mir space station are entering uncharted territory in efforts to repair damage caused by collision with supply vehicle that has caused severe loss of electrical power; Russian commander, Vasily Tsibliyev, veteran cosmonaut who has had five spacewalks and has spent long periods in space, bluntly warns he has no training in repair techniques, and that performing mission successfully will be impossible; apart from lack of training, crew must also use special equipment only now being built; job will require unusual dexterity, including maneuvering through narrow portal to damaged module while wearing bulky space suit; photo; diagram (M)

headline.main: Mir Astronauts Now Facing Uncharted Territory

results.snippet: Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander of the Mir space station, has had his brushes with danger. The veteran Russian Air Force pilot, 43, has made five space walks and spent long periods in space. He had endured a dangerous fire, which filled Mir with...
results.lead_paragraph: Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander of the Mir space station, has had his brushes with danger. The veteran Russian Air Force pilot, 43, has made five space walks and spent long periods in space. He had endured a dangerous fire, which filled Mir with smoke and splattered chucks of molten metal around the space station. But the commander, who carries a plastic rabbit from his daughter as a good luck charm, has his worries about his new assignment: repairing the stricken Mir, which was severely damaged last week when a supply vehicle crashed into it.
